tree.original_reasoning:
We are given two programs to complete.

For program1.py:
We are reading n and q, then a list of n prices.
We sort the prices in descending order and then build a prefix sum array 'a' such that a[i] is the sum of the first i items (which are the most expensive i items because we sorted in descending order).

However, note that the problem requires: for a query (x, y), the customer must purchase at least x items and then the y cheapest of those purchased are free. The strategy is to buy exactly x items (because buying more might not help since we can only get y free and we want the maximum free value) and then the free items are the y cheapest in that set. To maximize the free value, we want the set of x items to have the largest possible y cheapest items. This is equivalent to: we take the x items that are the most expensive (so that the cheapest y among them are as large as possible). But note: the free items are the cheapest in the set. So if we take the top x most expensive items, then the cheapest y in that set are the last y of the sorted (in ascending order) of these x. However, we sorted in descending order.

Alternatively, we can sort the entire list in ascending order. Then the free items would be the first y of the selected set? But note: we want the maximum free value. Actually, we want the set of x items that has the largest possible y smallest items. This is achieved by taking the largest x items (so that the smallest among them are as large as possible). 

So let's sort the prices in ascending order: then the largest x items are the last x. The y smallest in that set are the first y of the last x?
